HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system, making it difficult to fight off infections and diseases. AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is a condition that develops when HIV has progressively damaged the immune system, making the body vulnerable to opportunistic infections and cancers.

According to UNAIDS, there were approximately 38 million people living with HIV worldwide in 2019, with 1.7 million new infections occurring that year. HIV can be transmitted through sexual contact, sharing of needles, mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding, and blood transfusions (although this is rare in developed countries).

It is important to note that HIV and AIDS are manageable with proper treatment and care. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is a combination of medications that can suppress the virus, slow down its progression, and prevent transmission to others.
